Edward O. Wilson is Honorary Curator in Entomology and University Research Professor Emeritus, Harvard University.
He has received more than 100 awards for his research and writing, including the U. S. National Medal of Science, the Crafoord Prize and two Pulitzer Prizes in non-fiction.
His most recent book is “The Social Conquest of Earth.”
shownText:
But we are still part of earth’s fauna and flora.
Contrary to general opinion, demons and gods do not vie for our allegiance.
We are bound to it by emotion, physiology, and not least, deep history.
Exalted we are indeed, risen to be the mind of the biosphere without a doubt, our spirits capable of awe and ever more breathtaking leaps of imagination.
Self-understanding is what counts for long-term survival, both for individuals and for the species.
We are self-made, independent, alone and fragile.
It is dangerous to think of this planet as a way station to a better world, or continue to convert it into a literal, human-engineered spaceship.
We will also, I believe, take a more serious look at our place in nature.

Edward O. Wilson is Honorary Curator in Entomology and University Research Professor Emeritus, Harvard University.
He has received more than 100 awards for his research and writing, including the U. S. National Medal of Science, the Crafoord Prize and two Pulitzer Prizes in non-fiction.
His most recent book is “The Social Conquest of Earth.”
